title: Prague: a guide to the best hotels, shops and restaurants
text:
Prague Prague: a guide to the best hotels, shops and restaurants It may be known for its ancient architecture and beer, but there is a lot more to discover during a city break in Prague Historic Malá Strana Photo: Courtesy of the Mandarin Oriental Prague By Jemma Blundell Comments Stay 
Set among the palaces and gardens of the historic Malá Strana district, the Mandarin Oriental , Prague is built on the site of a 14th-century monastery and is utterly peaceful. 
If you’re looking for something a little more modern and quirky, try the Hotel Josef , with its comfy beds and funky bathrooms. The staff write a blog of upcoming cultural events as an insider’s guide. 
Drinks with a view at the Mandarin Oriental Presidential Terrace. Photo: Courtesy of Mandarin Oriental Eat 
Field’s ethos is “garden to plate”: local, seasonal food, exquisitely presented. 
La Bottega Tusarova has mastered the art of simple Italian food. The bistro doubles as a shop where you can buy many of the Italian ingredients used in the kitchen as well as books and tableware. 
La Bottega Tusarova Photo: Courtesy of La Bottega Tusarova Drink 
Prague is famous for its refreshing beer, and the Pivoval Marina Brewery , on the riverside at Holešovice port, is just the place to sample it. 
Kick back after a long day’s sightseeing with a couple of glasses of Prosecco, imported from northern Italy, at Prosekárna . Your host will offer in-depth knowledge on the variety of flavours as well as a few tasty nibbles. 
The Prosekárna bar Photo: Courtesy of Prosekárna Shop 
Prague is world-famous for its glass craftsmanship, but a lot of places will lure in tourists with inauthentic products. The unique designs at the wonderfully bohemian Material , however, are fabulous and definitely worth adding to your tableware collection. 
Students and young designers founded Parazit Fashion Shop to sell their limited-edition pieces. They offer quirky fashion and adorable accessories. 
Browse pieces by upcoming designers at Parazit Fashion Shop. Photo: Courtesy of Parazit Fashion Shop Do 
If you want to explore the modern side to Prague, make sure to stop at the starkly industrial Dox Centre for Contemporary Art . Since its opening in 2008, this groundbreaking gallery has marked a new beginning in the Czech cultural scene. 
For a bird’s-eye view of the city, climb the 216m-high Žižkov Television Tower . Built in the 1980s before the communist regime collapsed, it is now embraced by the Czech people. Don’t forget to look out for the sculptures by artist David Cerný on its side. Spa 
Built in a former Renaissance chapel, The Spa at Mandarin Oriental has won many awards. Book an Oriental Essence body massage, where you are able to choose your own essential oils before being pampered from head to foot. Relax blissfully in the Tea Lounge afterwards. Fly With 
British Airways flies to Prague from £49 each way. Kirker Holidays offers three-night stays at Mandarin Oriental, Prague, from £749 pp including flights, transfers and breakfast.
